newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech cabinet begins pension reform debate.
newsitem.headline: Czech cabinet begins pension reform debate.

text.p: Czech ministers opened a debate on Tuesday on a plan to switch the country's pay-as-you-go pension system into a model incorporating mandatory private savings, Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus said.
"There is universal agreement that the current system has its problems, and sooner or later a clash with its limits would come," Klaus told reporters after a ministerial meeting.
He said the new system should include the current form of financing plus private mandatory savings and voluntary pension insurance.
Klaus said that the social affairs ministry wanted the new sytem to start running in 1999, but he added that any changes would not apply to people nearing pension age at that time.

The prime minister added that debates would continue on the crucial "parameters" of the new system which will set proportions between the pay-as-you-go arrangement and priavte savings for individuals' pensions.
Some economists have called for a change of the system as the current one might become unfinancable as the average age of the Czech population continues to rise.
